learning_outcomes.description: Examine and evaluate the fundamental concepts of the mining process value chain, including ore fragmentation and mineral liberation principles.
Analyse the influence of geotechnical and geometallurgical data on fragmentation outcomes and final recovery across the stages of rock blasting, crushing and grinding.
Evaluate the key components of blasting engineering design, including objective setting, blast domain characterisation, drilling system selection, and explosive selection criteria.
Assess the relationship between explosive properties, detonation performance, rock mass damage mechanisms, and resultant fragmentation outcomes.

Apply analytical and empirical models to predict and evaluate blasting outcomes, including rock mass damage, fragmentation distribution, muckpile characteristics, ground vibration, and air blast overpressure.
Evaluate downstream process modelling requirements and design alternatives to achieve specific targets, incorporating socio-environmental considerations, and continuous improvement strategies.
Design and implement mine-to-mill optimisation strategies, using collaborative approaches to address complex operational challenges.
Evaluate design implementation procedures, safety protocols, and regulatory requirements, ensuring compliance with industry standards and best practices.
Work professionally and equitably as a group to analyse blast design alternatives using technical concepts and recommend an optimal design solution.

assessments.assessment_title: Completion of online module Quizzes and Portfolio of PBL Activities 1 to 5
assessments.task_description:
Evidence of completion of online module quizzes and submission of portfolio of on-campus PBL activities 1 to 5.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Note that online module quizzes should automatically populate Blackboard after completion. Portfolio of activities 1 to 5 must be submitted through a link provided in Blackboard as a single PDF document on the due date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Group Drilling and Blasting Design and Optimisation project
assessments.due_date:
Progress update presentations 8/10/2025 11:00 am

Final written report 24/10/2025 5:00 pm
assessments.task_description:
Details of the group Drilling and Blasting Project will be provided in Week 3 of the course. The overall mark will consist of two components:

- A brief presentation (progress report) worth 10% of the total mark  

- A final written report worth 90% of the total mark 

Note that a group peer review will need to be submitted to evaluate the contribution of each team member.

If, for whatever reason, you find that your group is not functioning effectively, please contact your Course Coordinator for support.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Progress presentations in PowerPoint or PDF format must be submitted via the link provided in Blackboard. The Final group report must be submitted via Turnitin through the available link.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Course Introduction

Online session covering overall course structure including online modules and face to face Problem Based Learning activities. This session also discusses assessment requirements and overall expectations.


Learning outcomes: L01

learning_activities.topic:
The Mining Value Chain

Complete the online module and quiz before the scheduled problem based learning activity. This module provides a brief description of theory of constraints and how it relates to mine process optimisation. This module also provides practical examples of the mining value chain and the impact of drill and blast on downstream activities.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02

This module also provides practical examples of the mining value chain and the impact of drill and blast on downstream activities.
